prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For refusing to buy any of my family members a christmas gift?
Now, based off of the title, you probably already think “Damn, this kid’s an asshole.” But here’s some context.

The week before Christmas, I received a $400 target gift card I won in a drawing.  I bragged about it on Instagram, where my sister follows me on, and of course, she saw it. She gave me a phone call and asked me who gave it to me, and I explain the situation, and tell her specifically NOT TO TELL MOM, as I knew it was bad enough that my sister knew already. She hangs up, and a few minutes later, my mother comes bursting into my room. She asks to see the gift card, and I hand it to her. She gives it back, then she says, obnoxiously, “You have to get something for me and (Sister’s name), That frustrated me enough, but I agreed, (I am VERY conservative, especially with my money.) 

Then when I was at target, getting my stuff plus what I WAS gonna get for my mom and sister, I get a phone call from my mom. 

Mom: “Oh, also, you have to get something for (Cousin 1’s name) and (Cousin 2’s name,) as well. Be thoughtful, don’t just get something cheap.” She said, even more obnoxiously 

(We were visiting my Uncle and Aunt for christmas, and my cousins are 6 and 2, so why the hell would I need to spend that much money on two more people I don’t and won’t see often?)

Me: “No thanks.” I then hung up the phone and ignored the rest of my mom’s texts and phone calls.

I spoiled myself, changing my mind about getting anyone else anything, because of how obnoxious everyone was being towards me after finding out what I had, so I spoiled myself. Bought myself a pair of airpods, GTA V, PlayStation Plus,a cheap laptop to do work on, and some new wrestling gear. Also bought a buddy of mine a bluetooth speaker, and spent the rest on candy and whatnot. 

Walked home and my mother was expecting that I got everyone a gift. Boy, was she shocked (despite our last phone call.) I got an ass chewing and she tried to guilt trip me, (unsuccessfully.) 

We were arguing then I just said “Maybe if you weren’t being so greedy about the situation, and kept your paws off of my money, I wouldn’t have changed my mind about getting you guys something!” (My exact words with some stuttering in it,) 

She then yelled at me a final time, marched to her room, and slammed her door. 

Typing that first paragraph made my blood boil, and reminded me of why I’m gonna keep all future assets private to me and me only. 

I’m 15 years old, if that will affect your criticism at all. 





"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this question. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for refusing to buy Christmas gifts for family members after receiving a $400 gift card. The author is 15 years old, which I should consider.

First, I need to understand the situation. The author won a gift card and posted about it on Instagram. Their sister saw it, and the author told her not to tell their mom. But the mom found out anyway, entered the room, and insisted the author buy gifts for the mom, sister, and even cousins. The author felt pressured and decided to use the gift card for themselves instead, leading to a confrontation with the mom.

Now, to determine if the author is in the wrong. The key points here are the expectations around gift-giving and the family dynamics. The author was given the gift card as a personal prize. They didn't initially plan to use it for others but changed their mind after the mom and sister intervened. The mom then expected more gifts, even adding cousins, which the author found unreasonable, especially since they don't see these cousins often. 

In many cultures, giving gifts to family during Christmas is a common tradition. However, the author is only 15, and their perspective might be different. The mom's behavior seems to be a factor here—she took the gift card and then added more people, which the author felt was greedy. The author's response was to cancel the family gifts and use the money for themselves, which might be seen as selfish, but their age and financial responsibility (being conservative) could mitigate that.

The author's argument is that the family was being greedy and pushing for more, so they decided to keep the gift card. The mom's reaction was harsh, and the author felt justified in standing up for themselves. Considering the mom's role in escalating the situation and the author's age, there might be a valid reason for their stance. However, the expectation to give gifts in a family setting is strong, so not giving any might be seen as inconsiderate.

But the author was already pressured to give gifts they weren't prepared to give, and the mom's reaction after the author stood their ground is problematic. The author might not be in the wrong because they were within their right to decide how to use the gift card they received. The family's behavior, especially the mom's, could be seen as the root issue. So, while the author's choice to not give gifts might be frowned upon, the context suggests it's not entirely their fault. The answer is likely B, No.
